page.title: 12Sparham Agriculture
page.content: Most of the land in Sparham is owned and farmed by one family, who have lived there for several generations. The major part of the land is arable growing a variety of crops including wheat, barley, sugar beet, oil seed rape and rye-grass. Some of the land borders a 3 mile stretch of river which is let. The watermeadows fatten cattle. 200 acres is woodland, farmed with oaks for future generations thereby helping with the dreaded Capital Transfer Tax. The oak is interspersed with other trees which all have an earlier harvest. This woodland provides natural cover for wildlife. There is a disused brick-kiln which was used to provide bricks for all the buildings.
